entry.title: Any Code of Your Own That You Haven't Looked at for Six or More Months Might as Well Have Been Written by Someone Else.
entry.content: “Any code of your own that you haven’t looked at for six or more months might as well have been written by someone else.” – Unknown – Eagleson’s Law

entry.title: Without Requirements or Design, Programming Is the Art of Adding Bugs to an Empty Text File.
entry.content: “Without requirements or design, programming is the art of adding bugs to an empty text file.” – Louis Srygley

entry.title: When Debugging, Novices Insert Corrective Code; Experts Remove Defective Code.
entry.content: “When debugging, novices insert corrective code; experts remove defective code.” – Richard Pattis

entry.title: Walking on Water and Developing Software From a Specification Are Easy if Both Are Frozen.
entry.content: “Walking on water and developing software from a specification are easy if both are frozen.” – Edward V. Berard

entry.title: There Are Two Ways of Constructing a Software Design: One Way Is to Make It So Simple That There Are Obviously No Deficiencies, and the Other Way Is to Make It So Complicated That There Are No Obvious Deficiencies. The First Method Is Far More Difficult.
entry.content: “There are two ways of constructing a software design: One way is to make it so simple that there are obviously no deficiencies, and the other way is to make it so complicated that there are no obvious deficiencies. The first method is far more difficult.” – C.A.R. Hoare

entry.title: There Is Not Now, Nor Has There Ever Been, Nor Will There Ever Be, Any Programming Language in Which It Is the Least Bit Difficult to Write Bad Code.
entry.content: “There is not now, nor has there ever been, nor will there ever be, any programming language in which it is the least bit difficult to write bad code.” – Unknown – Flon’s Law

entry.title: Some People, When Confronted With a Problem, Think 'I Know, I'll Use Regular Expressions.' Now They Have Two Problems.
entry.content: “Some people, when confronted with a problem, think “I know, I’ll use regular expressions.” Now they have two problems.“ – Jamie Zawinski

entry.title: In Theory, There Is No Difference Between Theory and Practice. but, in Practice, There Is.
entry.content: “In theory, there is no difference between theory and practice. But, in practice, there is.” – Jan L. A. van de Snepscheut

entry.title: If Debugging Is the Process of Removing Software Bugs, Then Programming Must Be the Process of Putting Them In.
entry.content: “If debugging is the process of removing software bugs, then programming must be the process of putting them in.” – Edsger Dijkstra

entry.title: First, Solve the Problem. Then, Write the Code.
entry.content: “First, solve the problem. Then, write the code.” – John Johnson

entry.title: Deleted Code Is Debugged Code.
entry.content: “Deleted code is debugged code.” – Jeff Sickel

entry.title: Debugging Is Twice as Hard as Writing the Code in the First Place. Therefore, if You Write the Code as Cleverly as Possible, You Are, by Definition, Not Smart Enough to Debug It.
entry.content: “Debugging is twice as hard as writing the code in the first place. Therefore, if you write the code as cleverly as possible, you are, by definition, not smart enough to debug it.” – Brian Kernighan

entry.title: Computer Science Education Cannot Make Anybody an Expert Programmer Any More Than Studying Brushes and Pigment Can Make Somebody an Expert Painter.
entry.content: “Computer science education cannot make anybody an expert programmer any more than studying brushes and pigment can make somebody an expert painter.” – Eric S. Raymond

entry.title: A Good Programmer Is Someone Who Always Looks Both Ways Before Crossing a One-way Street.
entry.content: “A good programmer is someone who always looks both ways before crossing a one-way street.” – Doug Linder

entry.title: Any Fool Can Make Something Complicated. It Takes a Genius to Make It Simple
entry.content: “Any fool can make something complicated. It takes a genius to make it simple.” – Woody Guthrie

entry.title: Any Application That Can Be Written in JavaScript, Will Eventually Be Written in JavaScript
entry.content: “Any application that can be written in JavaScript, will eventually be written in JavaScript.” – Jeff Atwood – Atwood’s Law

entry.title: Premature Optimization Is the Root of All Evil
entry.content: “We should forget about small efficiencies, say about 97% of the time: premature optimization is the root of all evil. Yet we should not pass up our opportunities in that critical 3%.” – Donald Knuth

entry.title: Bad Behavior Arises When You Abstract People Away From the Consequences of Their Actions
entry.content: “Bad behavior arises when you abstract people away from the consequences of their actions.” – Jez Humble

entry.title: User Stories Are Just Options, Not Commitment
entry.content: “User stories are just options, not commitment.” – Gojko Adzic

entry.title: Unless Scope Is Flexible, Organisations Do Not Benefit From Agile
entry.content: “Unless scope is flexible, organisations do not benefit from agile.” – Gojko Adzic
